Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: An HOA inspection is scheduled and items left in the corridor could be cited for blocking an emergency exit.
Situation2: The ambulance is transporting a critically ill patient through a severe thunderstorm with slick roads and low visibility.
Story:
I woke up to the sound of rain hammering the windows, my mind already racing. The HOA inspection was today, and I remembered my neighbor’s stroller still parked in the corridor. We’d been warned: anything blocking the exit would be cited. As a neighbor, I wanted to be considerate, to remind her gently or move it myself, but I barely had time to think before my phone buzzed—an emergency call. I was needed at the hospital, now.

Minutes later, I was behind the wheel of the ambulance, sirens wailing, a critically ill patient in the back. The storm was relentless, water pooling on the roads, visibility near zero. Every instinct screamed at me to slow down, to drive safely for my patient and my partner. But I couldn’t shake the image of the stroller in the corridor, the risk it posed, the trouble it could cause for my neighbor—and for me, as a member of this community.

Torn between my duty to my patient and my responsibility as a neighbor, I gripped the wheel tighter, heart pounding, knowing I couldn’t meet both expectations at once.
